Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research: Investigating the Role of Psychosocial Factors on Students Taking Gatekeeper Courses in STEM

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project investigates the psychosocial factors that influence learning and performance for undergraduate students taking introductory science and mathematics courses at North Carolina Central University. The project extends prior research where the investigator found that among the factors measured on a learning motivation and strategies questionnaire, the studentsâ€™ expressed self-efficacy was found to be the strongest predictor of course performance, and was the singular predictor when controlling for prior achievement. The current study will use a generalized latent subgroup approach to allow for a finer-grained analysis that could detail relationships or interactions that might be missed otherwise. The project illustrates the possibilities a generalized latent subgroup perspective yields for addressing the complexity and heterogeneity of broadening participation STEM education research.

The research explores the intersection of the multiple dimensions of a generalized population, characterized by socioeconomic status, environmental and situational factors, personal and social identities, and motivational states of students, and corresponding relationships with behavioral and academic outcome variables associated with them taking gatekeeper STEM courses. The study will examine four research questions: (1) What generalized latent subgroups are determined from background characteristics, motivational, and psychological variables?, (2) Do background characteristics, motivational, and psychological variables interact to influence learning behavior in STEM courses?, (3) To what extent does the psychosocial and behavioral factors associated with learning determine academic outcomes, such as pass rates and retention in STEM courses? And (4) What differential effects are reflected on learning behaviors and academic outcomes in STEM courses from generalized subgroups? Survey data will be collected from students in introductory STEM courses and analyzed using Latent Class Analysis as a methodological approach. The research results can contribute to more effective interventions to improve retention of underrepresented groups in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the project was to investigate the psychosocial factors that influence learning and performance outcomes for students taking introductory science and mathematics courses at North Carolina Central University (NCCU). This project took a novel approach to explore the identity-to-behavior link by applying broadly the concept of group membership in investigating the intersection of individual, contextual, psychosocial, and motivational characteristics for determining multidimensional, descriptive identity profiles. 

Intellectual Merit:

We conducted analyses on archived dataset from a Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ) survey. We considered traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables used to predict college performance, specifically, gender parents marital status, parents educational level, household income, HSGPA and SAT score. Only HSGPA and the SAT score were found to be significant in predicting course performance. Next, we found that only one of the nine MSLQ scales, the Self-efficacy scale was significant in predicting course performance--end-of-course grade. The 4-class precollege-sociodemographic model variable for the MSLQ data was a significant and strong predictor of STEM course performance. Interestingly, we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were high precollege achievers compared in STEM course performance to students from two-parent, high-income households who were high precollege achievers. And we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were low precollege achievers compared in STEM course performance to students from two-parent, high-income households who were low precollege achievers. We conducted similar analyses on  archived dataset  from a motivation survey (MUSIC Model of Academic Motivation) and found similar results. 
We collected data on NCCU freshman STEM majors Fall 2011 to Fall 2023 that included the same traditional predictors variables. We regressed STEM retention rate on traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables. Only gender and HSGPA were found to be significant predictors 1st-, 2nd-, and 3rd-year retention rate in STEM. We also regressed STEM graduation rate on traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables. Likewise, only gender and HSGPA were found to be significant predictors 4th-, 5th-, and 6th-year graduation rate in STEM. We then found a 4-class precollege-sociodemographic model, and this variable was a significant and strong predictor of STEM retention and graduation rates. We found students from single-parent, low-income households who were high precollege achievers compared in STEM retention and graduation to students from two-parent, high-income households who were high precollege achievers. And we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were low precollege achievers compared in STEM retention and graduation to students from two-parent, high-income households who were low precollege achievers.These results provided strong support that the 'person-oriented' precollege profile model is a worthwhile new variable to consider towards gaining a more nuanced understanding of the effect that sociodemographic, precollege achievement, motivation, and identity factors have on academic outcomes of STEM students at an HBCU.

Broader Impacts:

That available motivation measures (MUSIC, MSLQ) have factor structures that do not fit the data from samples of African American students in STEM courses at NCCU, and that African American students socioeconomic backgrounds and other precollege characteristics define distinct group membership, revealed a critical need for a new valid measure of motivation and STEM identity for the African American population.  A ground-up development of measures was conducted through a mixed-methods research process. For the study, 'STEM Wakanda at NCCU', data  were collected from focus groups who were students in STEM courses at NCCU. The results of the qualitative analysis were four emergent themes, Black Excellence in STEM, Environment and Support at an HBCU, STEM Aspirations, and Sense of Community. Intrigued by the 'Black Excellence in STEM' theme, we carried out small group cognitive interviewing. The focus group interviews addressed student experiences and factors contributing to their success. Students reflected on various aspects of the campus community that enhanced their experiences, along with their perceptions of Black excellence and how it was represented on campus. We constructed a repeated-ratings survey instrument to empirically assess students experiences associated with socialization messages about Black excellence among various institutional agents, as well as the extent to which these institutional agents contributed to students feelings of belonging at the institution. Institutional agents included university peers, university alumni, professors, advisors, student leaders, administrators, and clubs/organizations, as well as self, were the sources transmitting the Black excellence socialization and belonging messages. We used multilevel linear modeling to address research questions. To assess whether socialization toward Black Excellence explains variation in HBCU STEM students perceptions of different institutional agents contributions to their belonging, ratings of school belonging were regressed on student ratings of socialization towards Black excellence from various institutional agents. Results revealed that the more institutional agents provided HBCU students with socialization messages about Black Excellence, the more students rated those institutional agents as contributing to their sense of belonging at the university. Our model provides a solid foundation for future research by demonstrating strong overall model quality, significant associations, and effect sizes.


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Caesar R Jackson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overall goal of the project was to investigate the psychosocial factors that influence learning and performance outcomes for students taking introductory science and mathematics courses at North Carolina Central University (NCCU). This project took a novel approach to explore the identity-to-behavior link by applying broadly the concept of group membership in investigating the intersection of individual, contextual, psychosocial, and motivational characteristics for determining multidimensional, descriptive identity profiles. Intellectual Merit: We conducted analyses on archived dataset from a Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ) survey. We considered traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables used to predict college performance, specifically, gender parents marital status, parents educational level, household income, HSGPA and SAT score. Only HSGPA and the SAT score were found to be significant in predicting course performance. Next, we found that only one of the nine MSLQ scales, the Self-efficacy scale was significant in predicting course performance--end-of-course grade. The 4-class precollege-sociodemographic model variable for the MSLQ data was a significant and strong predictor of STEM course performance. Interestingly, we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were high precollege achievers compared in STEM course performance to students from two-parent, high-income households who were high precollege achievers. And we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were low precollege achievers compared in STEM course performance to students from two-parent, high-income households who were low precollege achievers. We conducted similar analyses on archived dataset from a motivation survey (MUSIC Model of Academic Motivation) and found similar results. We collected data on NCCU freshman STEM majors Fall 2011 to Fall 2023 that included the same traditional predictors variables. We regressed STEM retention rate on traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables. Only gender and HSGPA were found to be significant predictors 1st-, 2nd-, and 3rd-year retention rate in STEM. We also regressed STEM graduation rate on traditional sociodemographic and precollege achievement variables. Likewise, only gender and HSGPA were found to be significant predictors 4th-, 5th-, and 6th-year graduation rate in STEM. We then found a 4-class precollege-sociodemographic model, and this variable was a significant and strong predictor of STEM retention and graduation rates. We found students from single-parent, low-income households who were high precollege achievers compared in STEM retention and graduation to students from two-parent, high-income households who were high precollege achievers. And we found students from single-parent, low-income households who were low precollege achievers compared in STEM retention and graduation to students from two-parent, high-income households who were low precollege achievers.These results provided strong support that the 'person-oriented' precollege profile model is a worthwhile new variable to consider towards gaining a more nuanced understanding of the effect that sociodemographic, precollege achievement, motivation, and identity factors have on academic outcomes of STEM students at an HBCU. Broader Impacts: That available motivation measures (MUSIC, MSLQ) have factor structures that do not fit the data from samples of African American students in STEM courses at NCCU, and that African American students socioeconomic backgrounds and other precollege characteristics define distinct group membership, revealed a critical need for a new valid measure of motivation and STEM identity for the African American population. A ground-up development of measures was conducted through a mixed-methods research process. For the study, 'STEM Wakanda at NCCU', data were collected from focus groups who were students in STEM courses at NCCU. The results of the qualitative analysis were four emergent themes, Black Excellence in STEM, Environment and Support at an HBCU, STEM Aspirations, and Sense of Community. Intrigued by the 'Black Excellence in STEM' theme, we carried out small group cognitive interviewing. The focus group interviews addressed student experiences and factors contributing to their success. Students reflected on various aspects of the campus community that enhanced their experiences, along with their perceptions of Black excellence and how it was represented on campus. We constructed a repeated-ratings survey instrument to empirically assess students experiences associated with socialization messages about Black excellence among various institutional agents, as well as the extent to which these institutional agents contributed to students feelings of belonging at the institution. Institutional agents included university peers, university alumni, professors, advisors, student leaders, administrators, and clubs/organizations, as well as self, were the sources transmitting the Black excellence socialization and belonging messages. We used multilevel linear modeling to address research questions. To assess whether socialization toward Black Excellence explains variation in HBCU STEM students perceptions of different institutional agents contributions to their belonging, ratings of school belonging were regressed on student ratings of socialization towards Black excellence from various institutional agents. Results revealed that the more institutional agents provided HBCU students with socialization messages about Black Excellence, the more students rated those institutional agents as contributing to their sense of belonging at the university. Our model provides a solid foundation for future research by demonstrating strong overall model quality, significant associations, and effect sizes.
